instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3125: What is CD3125? This is a common typo,  the person typing CD3125 was most likely referring to CD3215.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message:
No H2O on this board.

When testing the usb power would cycle on / off
I discovered one of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s was toast as a small hole was blown in it and it showed up quickly on thermal.   Replaced it and it stopped the bounce but PP3v42 was a little low and the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s were not talking to the charger and switching it to18v.   Current draw was 0.08A at 5v.  Thermal quickly identified the other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> on the other side was also defective.   Regardless of port used it was the one sucking PP3v42 down slightly to 2.9-3.0v .   Replaced it and it and PP3V42 is now perfect.  Current draw is 0.02 it just sits at 5V and does not switch to 18v.   The CD3215C00's were replaced with the exact same part no the B03 versions.

Both defective <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s were on the same side of the board.   Should I just shotgun the ones on the other side?

No shorts on the power rails.  CPU / PCH are not shorted.

It has been about 6 months since I worked on these so I am just being a little lazy and looking for some guidance.


Thanks
Randall

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message: In my experience, when a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> has a hole in it, the CPU/PCH is toast. I've had 3 or 4 boards that had the <CHIP>CD3125</CHIP>'s shorted so badly they burned a hole into the chip itself and fused the ball to the pad below it (I believe all shorted @<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>), and in all 3 cases, I resolved the short and CPU was killed. Look very hard at the CPU/PCH chipset; sometimes you can see the short/damage on the actual face/resin area. Looks like a tiny crack/brown spot...almost impossible to see without a microscope of course. Usually accompanied by a weird diode reading--i.e. .118 or similar. You'll sometimes notice the voltage is low and weird too, like 1.27v (so not STG).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message:
<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips receive VBUS directly; and is 20V when working.
Depending of the way it gets burnt, input voltage can pass through (ms is sufficient) and sensitive chips from the board can be damaged; especially PCH/CPU and SMC.

You should check at least if all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips generate <SIGNAL>1V1_LDO</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message:
None of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s are producing <SIGNAL>1V1_LDO</SIGNAL>

I tested the CPU and PCH rails for shorts and did not find any as stated before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message:
1V1 LDO must appear only on the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> where the charger is connected.
Be sure to check that properly.
Compare diode mode readings for LDO outputs on all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
You should have problems on USB-C areas, if cannot get 1V1 LDO.

BTW, no short on PCH/CPU rails cannot assure you the chips are good!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message:
"BTW, no short on PCH/CPU rails cannot assure you the chips are good!"

Exactly! In fact, many times it WON'T show a short because it's not a total STG! Bet you have a dead CPU in this case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message:
I hear you that the odds are low but I want to use this to learn on.

Thanks 2informaticos,  I was measuring the 1v1 improperly.  The 1v1 signal is present on the side that was not damaged.   On the side I replaced the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s neither one will show <SIGNAL>1V1_LDO</SIGNAL>.  Diode checking the 1v8 and 3v3 shows .5v normal readings.   I compared them with the non damaged side. 

So.  Plugging into the non damaged side I get the 1v1 LDO signal on both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s but the machine will still not swith to the 18v.   On the damaged side where both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s were replaced I do not get 1v1 LDO but the diode readings are the same as the non damaged side and appear normal.  Both of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s on the damaged side were replaced.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message: There is a "chance" to got fake <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> pair chips...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message:
If you have a board with dead CPU, or other "letal" problem, but gets 20V on USB-C ports, do not scrap it.
Use it to test <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
These chips can be reballed in 10-20 min with solder paste...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message:
I harvested <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s from boards.  Reballed them and installed.
Still no 1v1 LDO

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message: How is the 1V1 LDO enabled?  What is the process?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> madness
threads.message: <SIGNAL>1V1_LDO</SIGNAL> is via <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and charger, and just means your <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is working fine "to that point" and communicating with charger. It rules out your <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> being "completely" bad and not even talking to charger. You check for LDO first because without it, you won't have anything beyond that. It's like confirming your car has gas, but doesn't explain why the car won't crank. Have to check beyond gas at that point.
